3681.caption: Ski School in The French Alpes - News - Getting Started and Equipment
3681.content:
[et_pb_section admin_label="section"][et_pb_row admin_label="row"][et_pb_column type="4_4"][et_pb_text admin_label="Text"] 09/08/2016 Beginner Ski Lesson #1.1 - Getting Started and Equipment In this lesson, Ski Instructor Darren Turner introduces the Ski School Beginners series of video tutorials and apps, talks about ski equipment and explains the different parts of a ski and their function. Welcome to your first day on skis. If you've never skied before we're going to take you through everything you need to know. Firstly we're going to have a quick look at the equipment to show you how to get the ski on and off and then sliding down the hill nice and gently on a very easy slope, the next thing is the first bit of control, a break called the snow plow and then finally putting some turns together so you can control your descent down the slope. It's a gorgeous day. Let's give it a go. First things first. The ski. Tip of the ski, tail of the ski. Bendy bit goes forward, nice and simple. Bindings - toe binding, heel binding. These are the things that are going to hold you on the ski and here we've got a ski break, basically when you're in the ski that will be out of the way. If you do take a tumble they release, break will pop down and stop that ski sliding down and killing someone. Underneath, plastic base - you're going to slide on this. On each side of that you've got a metal edge. If you hear anybody refer to the word edge they're talking about simply tipping the ski onto the side and using that metal edge. All you need to know. The heel binding has got two positions - closed and open. When you're in the ski it will be closed. To get yourself out you're going to have to place the ski stick in the hole in the back, push down firmly, lift your heel and you're out. But bear in mind if you do take a tumble there's a good chance the heel binding will still be close. So rather than spend ten minutes trying to get the ski on when it's already close, push down, open the binding, and you're ready to go again. Watch out for the rest of the series, download the apps, and remember for your safety that they are a supplement, not a replacement to on-slope tuition with a qualified ski instructor. If this skiing lesson is too basic for you, check out our Intermediate and Advanced apps and YouTube series. Ski School Beginners (v2.0) on the iTunes App Store: https://itunes.apple.com/gb/app/ski-school-beginners/id394635897?mt=8 https://youtu.be/AR7C5qWvuUc Click here for more local information about #whattoseeTheFrenchAlpes [avatar]

This post was created by LouisAndrews

This article was first published at http://ovonetwork.com/tag/whattosee #TheFrenchAlpes, #whattosee, #whattoseeTheFrenchAlpes, #vacationinTheFrenchAlpes, #holidayinTheFrenchAlpes [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section]

3743.caption: The French Alpes Ski School - General Lessons - Ski Boots - How to put them on
3743.content:
[html ] General Lessons Ski Boots - How to put them on https://youtu.be/gGsZH3SqO-I

Ski Boots - How to put them on

Ski Boots can be a challenge to put on for a beginner. Don't worry! Follow Darren's guide to putting on ski boots and ski in comfort.

Getting your boots on correctly is extremely important. Get it wrong and it can ruin your day and even possibly your week. Firstly it's worth investing in a couple of good pairs of ski socks, pull them up all the way, and make sure you just got one pair and no creases, nice and smooth. Open up your boot, make sure all the clips are off and then give a good push. I'm in. A little tap back onto your heel to make your foot and your ankle sit right in the back of the cup. Open up the clips and make sure the tongue is in the middle and in between the two plastic covers. Very important. Give it a pull. A little bit of a wiggle. And I'm ready to do the boot up.

Start off around the ankle. And I'm not trying to do it up too tight to start with. Just get the clips on and the velcro strap, give it a pull, nice and tight. That feels okay. And now I can start to gently do it up tighter. That's feeling pretty good.

Now you want it as firm and as tight as you can get it without feeling uncomfortable. It's very important that the boot and your foot isn't sliding around on the inside. A lot of people don't do the boot up too tight because they think it's going to hurt their foot, but in fact if you're too loose and you're swimming in the boot there's a good chance you're going to rub and create blisters which is not really what you're after. You're more likely to create a problem by having the boot too loose than too tight.

A thing with these modern clips, if you're in between two of the groups you can turn the clip making it shorter or longer to get it exactly where you want it. It's worth spending a time and extra few minutes getting that right will actually make a lot of difference.

Anything to do with the trousers like a cuff like this don't try and shove it on the inside. Put it over the boot, trousers down, and you're pretty good to go.

And if you have any problems on the first couple of runs it's worth just making sure that boot is right. Don't put it off and wait for lunch. Get the boots right. It will make a lot of difference.

Darren Turner, presenter of the Ski School series of Apps for iPhone, iPod touch and iPad has been teaching skiing for 22 years, in four countries and two continents and was a member of the England Ski Team. For the last eleven years he has been instructing in Serre Chevalier, France.

He holds the highest B.A.S.I qualification - the international ski teaching diploma and believes enjoyment and learning are strongly interlinked.

The Ski School series of Apps offer ski technique instruction using no-nonsense, easy-to-understand language in a format that you can take wherever you go.

Click here for more ski school videos #skischool [avatar]

This post was created by LouisAndrews


This article was first published at http://ovonetwork.com/tag/skischool #OVO, #skischool, #skiing, #lovovo #alps #winteriscoming

[/html]

[text tag="h4" css="margin-bottom:1em;"]June 15, 2015[/text]

[text tag="p"]The recipe for personal success: Find a need that beats your drum.[/text]

[text tag="h4" css="margin-bottom:1em;"]August 14, 2015[/text]

[text tag="p"]Trust that your rewards will come. And credit as heaven sent.[/text]

40.name: blog-home

2.caption: Sample Page
2.content:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!
2.name: sample-page
